title: MP Anna Soubry hails Leicester as centre for business success at Midlands Engine summit | Leicester Mercury
text:
Comments (0) 
Minister for Small Business Anna Soubry has hailed Leicester as a centre for excellence for fast-growing companies. 
Speaking at the inaugural Midlands Engine business summit, Ms Soubry said the city has "some of the fastest- growing businesses of anywhere in the whole of the UK". 
She said: "I think we could all do well to look at Leicester to see what is going on there, see where there is this huge success and can we learn from there and how can we embrace it in our Midlands Engine." 
The Midlands Engine initiative was announced by Business Secretary Sajid Javid in December. 
It is a collaboration between businesses and the public sector and its main objective is to boost productivity, attract inward investment, increase connectivity and build a regional tourism offer. 
Its overall aim is the creation of 300,000 jobs across the Midlands over the next 15 years. Communities minister Marcus Jones said the plan would give the Midlands the potential to grow by £34 billion by 2030. 
Read more: Our voice has to be heard 
Ms Soubry called for investment in skills to ensure young people in the Midlands are not left behind and do not feel disaffected in the wake of the Brexit vote. 
She told delegates at the conference, held at Nottingham Trent University, she believes many of those who voted for Brexit did so "as a protest" because they feel "left behind" by society. 
Ms Soubry said: "I think it's incredibly important that as a society and a region we recognise we don't have the young people with the skills level they need to have. 
"Yes, we have got fabulous, excellent universities. 
"We have some great further education colleges and we have some outstanding schools. 
"But frankly, we are not doing enough. In this region we have got to do something about a situation that we shall resolve no longer to tolerate." 
Read more: Nick Pulley named chairman of £250m Midlands Engine fund 
Sir John Peace, chairman of the Midlands Engine, said the region has a major role to play in the UK's economic future. 
He said: "At a time of real uncertainty for our nation, there has perhaps never been a more important time for our region to come together and demonstrate why we no longer wish to remain Britain's best kept secret. 
"The Midlands has much to be proud of and to celebrate. 
"It has an amazing history and a great heritage. We have a tradition of enterprise and of innovation. 
"We must harness that spirit and use it to energise our future as a place to do business at the heart of the fifth biggest economy in the world."
